document.docAuthor: Liu, Zhen, He, Jun-Hua, Chen, Xue-Xin & Gupta, Ankita
document.masterDocTitle: The ater-group of the genus Apanteles Foerster (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Microgastrinae) from China with the descriptions of forty-eight new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The ater-group of the genus Apanteles Foerster (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Microgastrinae) from China with the descriptions of forty-eight new species

heading.emphasis:
Key to species of ater- group of genus
Apanteles Foerster
from China

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Propodeum at most with a weakly defined areola and never with a costula ( Fig. 87d ); spiracle not entirely or in part enclosed by keels; propodeum to sides of areola with dull microsculpture or nearly smooth, or, if rather strongly rugose, then metacarp of fore wing hardly 1.5× longer than its distance from apex of marginal cell; small; dark-legged, with hind tibia deeply infuscate to blackish ( Fig. 89a ); tergites posterior to T2 always with a dull sheen............
2 ( eublemmae -subgroup)

- Metacarp long, usually distinctly longer than pterostigma and at least 3.0× as long as distance from apex of marginal cell (e.g. Fig. 87a )..................................................................................... 6

3 (2). Mesoscutum with characteristic dense, silvery pubescence which on posterior half becomes longer and silky (e.g. Fig. 89e ) ................................................................................................. 4
- Pubescence of mesoscutum shorter, of regular appearance ( Fig. 93d ).......................................... 5

4 (3). Propodeum 4.0× wider than long ( Fig. 89c ); penultimate flagellomere almost cubic; scutellum narrower posteriorly ( Fig. 89e )................................................................
A . cavitergita Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Propodeum 6.0× wider than long ( Fig. 97k ); penultimate flagellomere 1.4× longer than wide ( Fig. 97d ); scutellum wider posteriorly ( Fig. 97h ).......................................................
A . setosus Liu & Chen, sp.
nov.

5 (3). Vein cu-a of hind wing abruptly strongly curved at posterior half, distinctly longer than 1-1A ( Fig. 92h ); pterostigma small, 3.2× as long as its widest part ( Fig. 92h ); head less transverse in dorsal view ( Fig. 92d ).................................................................................................
A. lineatella Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Vein cu-a of hind wing slightly curved, not longer than 1-1A; pterostigma large, 2.5× as long as its widest part ( Fig. 93b ); head more transverse in dorsal view ( Fig. 93e ).............................
A. palliditegula Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
6(2). Ovipositor sheath shorter than length of hind tibia (e.g. Fig. 93a )............................................. 7
- Ovipositor sheath much longer, at least as long as length of hind tibia (e.g. Fig. 95d )............................. 9

- T1 narrow, strongly converged from base, 3.0× longer than hind width (
Fig. 87g
); vein r of fore wing arising from apex side of pterostigma ( Fig. 87a )...................................................
A. alticella Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

8(7). Head transverse in dorsal view, 2.2× as wide as long ( Fig. 93e ); antenna distinctly shorter than body length (0.8×), penultimate flagellomere cubic to slightly transverse; vannal lobe of hind wing beyond its widest part strongly concave ( Fig. 93a )......................................................................
A. longiala Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Head less transverse in dorsal view, nearly 1.9× as wide as long ( Fig. 91d ); antenna weakly longer than body length, penultimate flagellomere 1.8× longer than wide; vannal lobe of hind wing beyond its widest part straight ( Fig. 91f )..............................................................................
A. impunctus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

9(6). Posterior tangent to anterior ocellus just touching posterior ocelli; first submarginal cell of hind wing 1.6× wider than high ( Fig. 95b )........................................................................................ 10

- Posterior tangent to anterior ocellus weakly transecting posterior ocelli; first submarginal cell of hind wing subquadrate to quadrate......................................................................................... 11

10(9). Vein 1-R1 indistinctly shorter than pterostigma, 3.6× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Fig. 95a ).....; T2 4.3× wider than long in the middle, weakly curved into T3 apically ( Fig. 95e ); vannal lobe of hind wing beyond its widest part straight ( Fig. 95b )....................................................
A. rectala Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Vein 1-R1 weakly longer than pterostigma, 4.3× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Fig. 88d ); T2 2.4× wider than long in the middle, straight apically ( Fig. 88e ); vannal lobe of hind wing beyond its widest part slightly concave (
Fig. 88g
)..............................................................
A. aphanoiugum Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

11(9). Areola on propodeum open anteriorly ( Fig. 90a ); basal width 2.0× wider than apical width ( Fig. 90b ); mesopleuron shiny, anterior parts with shallow, indefinite punctures...................................
A. heichinensis Sonan, 1942

- Areola on propodeum closed anteriorly (
Fig. 96g
); basal width 1.4× wider than apical width (
Fig. 96g
); mesopleuron slightly shiny, anterior and upper parts dull with heavy, dense punctures ( Fig. 96h )..........
A. rhombos Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
12(1). Vannal lobe of hind wing beyond its widest part usually straight or slightly convex and with hairs.................. 13
- Vannal lobe of hind wing beyond its widest part usually concave, sometimes straight, and hairless................. 19

13(12). Metacarp short, 2.0–2.5× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Figs 10e , 104a
2
); posterior tangent to anterior ocellus not touching posterior ocelli ( Fig. 10b ); mesonotum with sparse, deep punctures, shiny along the middle line, posterior part of imaginary notaulic courses without longitudinal striations ( Fig. 10c )..............
A. argiope Nixon, 1965

14(13). Vannal lobe of hind wing beyond its widest part with a series of hairs ( Fig. 35c ); mesonotum with coarse strong punctures, obviously strongly aciculate between punctures ( Fig. 35e ).................................
A. dryas Nixon, 1965

17(15). Body yellowish brown; propodeum with complete areola, costula present, posterio-lateral field distinctly transverse.................................................................................
A. bakeri Wilkinson, 1932
- Body at most yellowish on basal tergites; propodeum incomplete areolate, costula absent or indistinct.............. 18

18(17). Mesonotum dull with strong, dense punctures, coarser at posterior end of notaulic courses (
Fig. 28g
); eyes (in dorsal view) about 2.0× longer than temple ( Fig. 28d )......................................
A. crassus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Mesonotum shiny with sparse punctures, impunctate medio-apically ( Fig. 4h ); eyes (in dorsal view) about 3.0× longer than temple ( Fig. 4d ).........................................................
A. ambultor Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
- Ovipositor sheath shorter than 1.5× length of hind tibia................................................... 24

21(20). Hind femur yellow ( Fig. 15a ); propodeum without median keel and areola incomplete ( Fig. 15e )............................................................................................
A. bialtus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Hind femur brown to black ( Fig. 41a ); propodeum with a median keel reaching to nearly middle part and areola complete but rather small ( Fig. 41d )..................................................
A. fundum Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
22(20). Posterior tangent to anterior ocellus far beyond posterior ocelli............................................. 23

- Posterior tangent to anterior ocellus virtually transecting posterior ocelli ( Fig. 5c ).....
A. amotus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

23(22). Disc of mesonotum without longitudinal striations at its posterior part ( Fig. 20c ); T2 3.8× wider than long in the middle ( Fig. 20b ); hind femur dark brown ( Fig. 20a )......................................
A. cannabis Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Disc of mesonotum with distinct longitudinal striations at its posterior part; T2 1.8× wider than long in the middle; hind femur yellow..........................................................................................................................................................
A. petilicaudium Song & Chen, 2002
- T1 parallel-sided, or slightly converged towards apex, or distinctly wedge-shaped............................... 27

25(24). Postero-lateral areas of propodeum bounded externally by a keel, not always well defined, lying parallel to lateral propodeal keel and forming a narrow, longitudinal zone with it ( Fig. 21d ); pterostigma decidedly short, broad, 2.3× as long as its widest part ( Fig. 21h )..................................................................
A. carpatus (Say, 1836)

26(25). T2 nearly as long as T3 (
Fig. 36g
); hind coxa and femur bright yellow (
Fig. 36g
); ovipositor sheath 0.7× longer than length of hind tibia ( Fig. 36h )....................................................
A. expansus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
27(24). Ovipositor sheath not or hardly longer than hind basitarsus................................................. 28
- Ovipositor sheath at least distinctly longer than hind basitarsus, usually much longer............................ 35
28(27). Costula of propodeum more or less distinctly defined..................................................... 29
- Vein 1-CU1 of fore wing forming an angle with vein cu-a at their junction ( Fig. 31b )............................ 30

30(29). Hind tarsomere 4 distinctly shorter than 5; metacarp rather short, about 3.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Figs. 31b ,
104g
1
); hind wing broad, length of 1-M distinctly shorter than distance between its distal extremity and apex of vannal lobe ( Fig. 31c )..........................................................
A. demades Nixon, 1965

- Hind tarsomere 4 hardly shorter than 5; metacarp fully 6.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Fig. 75a ); hind wing narrower, length of 1-M slightly shorter than distance between its distal extremity and apex of vannal lobe ( Fig. 75i ).............................................................................
A. sartamus Nixon, 1965

- Turned-over part of T1 not shiny, strongly rugose entirely (
Fig. 34g
); scutellum slightly shiny with shallow punctures entirely ( Fig. 34f )..........................................................
A. distributa Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

33(32). Ovipositor sheath hardly 0.8× as long as length of hind basitarsus ( Fig. 42e ); vein 1-R1 2.8× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Fig. 42a ); posterior tangent to anterior ocellus virtually transecting posterior ocelli ( Fig. 42d )............................................................................
A. fuscidentalis Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

34(31). Head wider (1.1×) than mesoscutum; face rather transverse, 0.6× as high as wide ( Fig. 66c ); penultimate flagellomere subcubic..................................................................
A. plureseta Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Head narrower (0.9×) than mesoscutum; face less transverse, 0.8× as high as wide ( Fig. 72d ); penultimate flagellomere 1.8× longer than wide...........................................................
A. salsala Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
- Ovipositor sheath at least about 3/4 length of hind tibia................................................... 41
36(35). Costula of propodeum more or less distinctly defined..................................................... 37

37(36). Hind femur black ( Fig. 52a ); pterostigma with basal whitish spot ( Fig. 52j ); scutellum strongly rugose-punctate as mesonotum ( Fig. 52e )...........................................................
A. longicoxa Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
- Hind femur yellow; pterostigma without basal whitish spot; scutellum at most shallowly punctate.................. 38

38(37). Most parts of metasoma, apical half of hind coxa, and scape with pedicel of antenna bright yellow ( Fig. 37a ); hind femur much thinner, 3.6× longer than wide ( Fig. 37a ); inner spurs of hind tibia long, 3/5 length of hind basitarsus................................................................................
A. flavibasalis Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Whole body brown to dark brown; hind femur thicker, at most 3.0× longer than wide; inner spurs of hind tibia shorter, 2/5 length of hind basitarsus............................................................................ 39

39(38). Disc of mesonotum with shallow punctures disappearing at large posterior part, interspaces not smaller than diameter of puncture ( Fig. 59b ); first submarginal cell of hind wing 1.5× wider than high ( Fig. 59h ); r and 2-SR of fore wing distinctly angled at junction ( Fig. 59a ).............................................
A. muscosalis Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

40(36). T1 strongly constricted from base ( Fig. 7f ); face rugulose or striate-punctate ( Fig. 7h ); posterior tangent to anterior ocellus virtually transecting posterior ocelli ( Fig. 7e )..................................
A. annosus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- T1 parallel-sided, slightly constricted at apical third ( Fig. 6i ); face finely punctate ( Fig. 6c ); posterior tangent to anterior ocellus not touching posterior ocelli ( Fig. 6b ).................................
A. angustus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
41(35). Basal several flagellomeres reddish yellow, elsewhere blackish brown ( Fig. 71a )............................... 42
43(41). Pterostigma pallid with a darker border, or rarely, yellowish................................................ 44
- Pterostigma evenly brown or utmost with whitish basal spot................................................ 77
- Costula of propodeum more or less distinctly defined..................................................... 60
- Propodeum nearly smooth, or, with a dull microsculpture, or, at most weakly rugose............................ 48

46(45). T1 parallel-sided, never constricted apically ( Fig. 77f ); medial keel on propodeum distinct and long ( Fig. 77f ); inner margin of eyes distinctly converged towards apex (
Fig. 77g
).......................
A. semicarinatus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- T1 slightly to strongly constricted apically; medial keel on propodeum absent or shorter; inner margin of eyes parallel-sided or subparallel-sided................................................................................ 47

47(46). Areola on propodeum complete with a medial keel basally ( Fig. 22c ); mesonotum with heavy striate-punctation at posterior end of notaulic courses ( Fig. 22h ); vertex between eye and posterior ocellus dull with dense and strong puncture ( Fig. 22d )........................................................................
A. carssus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Areola on propodeum incomplete and indefinite ( Fig. 70d ); mesonotum without rugosity and longitudinal striations at posterior end of notaulic courses (
Fig. 70g
); vertex between eye and posterior ocellus shiny with extremely shallow punctures ( Fig. 70c ).............................................................
A. radocoxa Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
48(45). T1 hardly narrowed at apex, parallel-sided or almost parallel-sided.......................................... 49

49(48). T2 not sharply angled laterally, angled at about 45 degrees; scutellum highly polished, more narrowed and conically raised apically.....................................................................
A. leptoura Cameron, 1909

- T2 very sharply angled laterally, angled at about 30 degrees; scutellum flattened and with vague punctation, less conically raised and less narrowed apically..................................................................... 50

50(49). Ovipositor sheath distinctly longer than hind tibia; spines along upper part of outer side of hind tibia numerous, closer.............................................................................
A. tachardiae Cameron, 1913
- Ovipositor sheath not longer than hind tibia; spines along upper part of outer side of hind tibia fewer, sparser......... 51

51(50). Distance between posterior ocelli distinctly greater than distance between one of them and eye-margin.......................................................................................
A. machaeralis Wilkinson, 1928

- Distance between posterior ocelli shorter than distance between one of them and eye-margin ( Fig. 16c )...........................................................................................
A. bisulcata Cameron, 1909
52(48). Each side of imaginary areola on propodeum polished, smooth, there being no trace of areola or keel behind spiracle.. 53

- Each side of areola on propodeum with rugosity at least in the place normally occupied by costula, there being at least parts a keel behind spiracle ( Fig. 45d )..............................................
A. importunus Wilkinson, 1928
- Ovipositor sheath at most 1.3× longer than hind tibia..................................................... 55

54(53). Mesoscutum distinctly transverse; penultimate flagellomere not or hardly longer than wide; T1 relatively shorter..................................................................................
A. angaleti Muesebeck, 1956

- Mesoscutum nearly as long as wide (
Fig. 53g
); penultimate flagellomere about 1.6× longer than wide; T1 much longer ( Fig. 53f ).................................................................
A. longidiscus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

55(53). T2 shorter than half length of T3 ( Fig. 67h ); tergites posterior to T2 matte; ovipositor sheath much wider ( Fig. 67a )..........................................................................
A. prominens Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

56(55). T2 half length of T3 ( Fig. 63h ); propodeum densely, rather evenly rugose ( Fig. 63c )............
A. oritias Nixon, 1965
- T2 distinctly over half length of T3; propodeum widely polished............................................ 57

57(56). Ovipositor sheath 0.8× as long as length of hind tibia ( Fig. 40c ); hind femur relatively thin, 3.4× longer than wide; penultimate flagellomere indistinctly longer than wide................................
A. fraxinus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

58(57). Vein cu-a of hind wing slightly longer than 1-1A (
Fig. 9g
); sulcus between T2 and T3 indistinct ( Fig. 9f ); face more transverse ( Fig. 9i )........................................................
A. aphanofossa Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
- Vein cu-a of hind wing shorter than 1-1A; sulcus between T2 and T3 distinct; face less transverse.................. 59

59(58). Penultimate flagellomere 1.8× longer than wide; mesonotum without punctures at apex, no any trace of rugosity between punctures at posterior end of notaulic courses ( Fig. 49f ); hind wing broad, length of 1-M distinctly shorter than distance between its distal extremity and apex of vannal lobe ( Fig. 49c ).................
A. lateroglabris Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Penultimate flagellomere 2.4× longer than wide; rugulose between punctures at posterior end of notaulic courses on mesonotum ( Fig. 13f ); hind wing less broad, length of 1-M indistinctly shorter than distance between its distal extremity and the apex of vannal lobe ( Fig. 13h ).........................................
A. attenuator Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

61(60). Body entirely red ( Fig. 19a ); ovipositor sheath 1.5× longer than length of hind tibia; ocelli larger ( Fig. 19c )....................................................................................
A. bulbus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Body dark brown to black; ovipositor sheath distinctly less than 1.5× length of hind tibia, usually as long as length of hind tibia; ocelli smaller ( Fig. 62e )........................................................................ 62

62(61). Claws strongly developed, strongly curved; posterior tangent to anterior ocellus far before posterior ocelli ( Fig. 61i ); areola rather small and indistinct ( Fig. 61h )...................................
A. ocellisublimus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Claws poorly developed; posterior tangent to anterior ocellus closer to posterior ocelli; areola usually large and distinct.. ................................................................................................ 63

64(63). T2+T3 yellow or reddish yellow; ovipositor sheath about 2/3 the length of hind tibia; temple with considerable rugosity................................................................................
A. mamitus Nixon, 1965

- Tergites dark brown entirely; ovipositor sheath at least about as long as hind tibia; temple at most with only trace of sculpture............................................................................................ 65

65(64). Ovipositor sheath about as long as hind tibia; hind coxa dull, evenly, finely, densely rugose; metacarp about 4.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell...............................................
A. hemara Nixon, 1965

- Ovipositor sheath distinctly longer than hind tibia; hind coxa shiny, not rugose-punctate; metacarp reaching near apex of marginal cell.................................................................
A. significans Walker, 1860

- Mesoscutum showing fine rugosity, the lines of notaulices not that rugose; head above without that coarse sculpture; propodeum shorter..................................................................................... 67
- Hind tarsus brownish or blackish throughout; fore wing hyaline; T1 longer.................................... 68

- T2 shorter, at least 3.1× wider than long in the middle; ovipositor sheath slightly shorter than hind tibia; vein r of fore wing distinctly angled with 2-SR...............................................
A. brevicarinis Song & Chen, 2002
70(69). Costulae on propodeum poorly defined, more or less wanting ( Fig. 3d ); ovipositor sheath much wider............... 71

- Costulae on propodeum well defined (
Fig. 30g
); ovipositor sheath narrow ( Fig. 30a )............
A. cypris Nixon, 1965

71(70). Vein r and 2-SR of fore wing curved at junction; posterior tangent to anterior ocellus far beyond posterior ocelli; metacarp 4.8× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell.......................
A. longiantenna Chen & Song, 2004

- Vein r and 2-SR of fore wing distinctly angled at junction ( Fig. 3b ); posterior tangent to anterior ocellus touching posterior ocelli (
Fig. 3g
); metacarp nearly 3.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Fig. 3b ).............................................................................................
A. altus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

72(69). Fore tarsus very short, tarsomere 2 hardly longer than wide; fore tarsomere 5 with a distinct spine...............................................................................................
A. sodalis ( Haliday, 1834 )
- Fore tarsus normal, tarsomere 2 very obviously longer than wide; fore tarsomere 5 without spine.................. 73
- Costulae on propodeum poorly defined, more or less wanting.............................................. 76

74(73). Antenna rather short, penultimate flagellomere hardly longer than wide; metacarp relatively short, about 4.0 to 5.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell; ovipositor sheath at most as long as hind tibia......................... 75

- Antenna longer, penultimate flagellomere about 1.5× longer than wide; metacarp longer, 6.3× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell; ovipositor sheath one-and-a-quarter times longer than hind tibia...............................................................................................
A. cavatithoracica Chen & Yang, 2001

75(74). Pterostigma merely slightly paler medially ( Fig. 76j ); ovipositor sheath about as long as hind tibia ( Figs 76a, h ); face more transverse, 0.7× as high as wide, with small, even punctures ( Fig. 76e ).........
A. scrobiculatus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Pterostigma pellucid entirely ( Fig. 81d ); ovipositor sheath distinctly slightly shorter than hind tibia; face less transverse, 0.8× as high as wide, shallowly coarsely punctate ( Fig. 81e )..............................
A. taragamae Viereck, 1912

76(73). Vertex behind ocelli smooth with extremely fine, transversal aciculation ( Fig. 26e ); ovipositor sheath slightly longer than hind tibia ( Fig. 26a ); metacarp longer, nearly 6.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Figs. 26f , 104e ).....................................................................................
A. clita Nixon, 1965
- Costula of propodeum more or less distinctly defined..................................................... 83

79(78). Vertex between eye and posterior ocellus slightly shiny with fine punctures ( Fig. 69d ); areola incomplete (open anteriorly) with U-shaped apex (
Fig. 69g
); vein r of fore wing perpendicular to pterostigma ( Fig. 69b )................................................................................................
A. quadra Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Vertex between eye and posterior ocellus shiny with extremely shallow punctures; areola complete with V-shaped apex; vein r of fore wing strongly oblique outwards............................................................... 80

- Punctures somewhat rugulose on and above sternaulus of mesopleuron ( Fig. 51b ); antenna distinctly shorter than body length, penultimate flagellomere weakly transverse; first submarginal cell of hind wing 1.7× wider than high ( Fig. 51d )...........................................................................
A. limus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

81(78). Pterostigma brown with basal spot and slightly pale apically ( Fig. 2e ); penultimate flagellomere 1.8× longer than wide.....................................................................
A. albummacula Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
- Pterostigma light brown without basal spot; penultimate flagellomere cubic or just longer than wide................ 82

82(81). Propodeum with a complete areola ( Fig. 56f ); ovipositor sheath as long as hind tibia; T2 subtriangular, 3.3× wider than long in the middle, strongly curved into T3 apically ( Fig. 56f ).....................
A. magastigma Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Propodeum without areola, somewhat depressed medially ( Fig. 1f ); ovipositor sheath distinctly longer than hind tibia (as long as metasoma); T2 rather transverse, 5.0–6.0× wider than long in the middle, not curved into T3 apically ( Fig. 1b )........................................................................
A. adoxophyesi Minamikawa, 1954
84(83). T2, or/and, T3 yellow to reddish yellow, obviously different from remaining tergites in colour ( Fig. 52h )............ 85
- T2 and T3 brown to black, colour as the remaining tergites................................................. 87

85(84). Hind femur black, in sharp contrast with the pale-yellow hind trochanter ( Fig. 52a ); T3 3.0× longer than T2 ( Fig. 52h ); tegula bright yellow ( Fig. 52e )...................................................
A. longicoxa Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
- Hind femur yellow entirely, or sometimes dark apically; T3 at most 2.0× longer than T2; tegula brown to black....... 86

87(84). T1 elongate, gradually narrowed from base towards apex, more or less wedge-shaped, or, converged from middle or beyond middle of T1, its horizontal part distinctly to considerably longer than wide................................... 88
- T1 shorter, never obviously wedge-shaped, frequently markedly to indistinctly narrowed posteriorly................ 93

89(88). Pterostigma very broad, 2.3× as long as its widest part ( Figs. 43b , 104k ); costula poorly defined ( Fig. 43e ); spines along upper part of outside of hind tibia strong, very dense................................
A. galleriae Wilkinson, 1932

- Pterostigma narrow, at least 2.6× as long as its widest part; costula strongly defined; spines along upper part of outside of hind tibia weak and sparse.......................................................................... 90

90(89). Vein r of fore wing arising from apex of pterostigma, 1.3× longer than 2-SR ( Fig. 48e ); ovipositor sheath 1.25× longer than hind tibia; postero-lateral area of propodeum bounded externally by a keel, not always well defined, lying parallel to lateral propodeal keel and forming a narrow, longitudinal zone with it ( Fig. 48c ).......
A. latericarinatus Song & Chen, 2001

- Vein r of fore wing arising from middle of pterostigma, 2.2× longer than 2-SR ( Fig. 33a ); ovipositor sheath as long as hind tibia; postero-lateral area of propodeum not bounded externally by a keel ( Fig. 33c )..........
A. dissimile Nixon, 1965

91(88). Claws strongly developed; pterostigma dark yellowish brown, without a small whitish basal spot ( Fig. 83h )..................................................................................
A. unguifortis Song & Chen, 2004
- Claws not developed; pterostigma brown, with a small whitish basal spot...................................... 92

92(91). Pterostigma much smaller, 3.2× as long as its widest part ( Fig. 82b ); first submarginal cell of hind wing much wider, 1.8× wider than high (
Fig. 82g
); T2 distinctly curved into T3 ( Fig. 82f )...................
A. tenuis Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
94(93). Three posterior fields on propodeum rugose; pterostigma with small whitish basal spot.......................... 95

- Three posterior fields on propodeum smooth, at most indistinctly weakly rugulose; pterostigma without whitish basal spot ................................................................................................ 96

96(94). Ultimate flagellomere not shrunken abruptly; vein r of fore wing strongly curved outwards ( Fig. 60b )..........................................................................................
A. nixoni Song & Chen, 2002

- Ultimate flagellomere shrunken abruptly; vein r of fore wing somewhat curved inwards ( Fig. 44b )........................................................................................
A. gracilicorne Song & Chen, 2004

97(93). Hind femur slightly brownish ( Fig. 46h ); scutellum dull with rugulose punctures entirely ( Fig. 46c ); metacarp 3.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Fig. 46b ).............................
A. jasmine Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Hind femur bright yellow; scutellum shiny smooth or with indefinite punctures laterally; metacarp at least 4.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell................................................................... 98
98(97). T1 parallel-sided or indistinctly converged apically....................................................... 99
99(98). Lateral polished field of scutellum reaching over half length of scutellum; hind coxa black...................... 100

- Lateral polished field of scutellum reaching not over half length of scutellum ( Fig. 55c ); hind coxa evenly reddish yellow (
Fig. 55g
).................................................................
A. lunata Song & Chen, 2004

101(100). Face transverse and less strongly punctate; metasoma 1.2× as long as mesosoma; first submarginal cell of hind wing 1.6× wider than high.........................................................
A. aspersus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

- Face less transverse and strongly punctate (
Fig. 12g
); metasoma nearly as long as mesosoma ( Fig. 12a ); first submarginal cell of hind wing one-and-a-third times wider than high ( Fig. 12h )...............
A. stigmaium Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.

103(98). Scutellum rather convex ( Fig. 17d ); pterostigma rather large, 2.3× as long as its widest part ( Fig. 17b ); temple rather short (
Fig. 17g
)............................................................
A. brevitempus Liu & Chen
, sp. nov.
- Scutellum less convex; pterostigma not that large; temple longer........................................... 104

104(103). Ovipositor sheath distinctly longer, almost 1.5× longer than hind tibia; ovipositor sheath wide...............................................................................................
A. stictipes Chen & Song, 2004
- Ovipositor sheath shorter, at most 1.3× longer than hind tibia; ovipositor sheath narrower....................... 105

106(105). Vein r and 2-SR of fore wing distinctly angled at the meeting ( Fig. 32b ); metacarp fully 6.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell ( Figs. 32b , 104h )....................................................
A. diocles Nixon, 1965

- Vein r and 2-SR of fore wing indistinctly angled at the meeting; metacarp at most 5.0× as long as its distance from apex of marginal cell.................................................................................... 107
107(106). Flagellomeres 12–15 about 1.6–1.7× longer than wide; vein r of fore wing perpendicular to pterostigma............ 108

- Flagellomeres 12–15 about 1.2–1.3× longer than wide; vein r of fore wing curved outwards ( Fig. 65b )....................................................................................
A. pellucipterus Song & Chen, 2001

108(107). Posterior tangent to anterior ocellus just before posterior ocelli ( Fig. 85c ); face quadrate ( Fig. 85h ); inner spurs of hind tibia hardly half length of hind basitarsus..........................................
A. verticalis Song & Chen, 2004

- Posterior tangent to anterior ocellus slightly transecting posterior ocelli ( Fig. 58f ); face transverse, 0.8× as high as wide ( Fig. 58b ); inner spurs of hind tibia 3/5 length of hind basitarsus................................
A. medon Nixon, 1965
